Publisher and Subscriber

 Publisher

A publisher publishes data to topics
A publisher has to have a name (for debugging purpose)
A topic is a named bus (need a name as well)
A topic must have a type associated with it (strongly typed)
Do not need to care who are subscribers (anonymous)

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 talker.py
#!/usr/bin/env python
import rospy
from std_msgs.msg import String
def talker():
pub = rospy.Publisher('chatter', String, queue_size=1)
rospy.init_node('talker', anonymous=True)
rate = rospy.Rate(10) # 10hz
while not rospy.is_shutdown():
hello_str = "hello world %s" % rospy.get_time()
rospy.loginfo(hello_str)
pub.publish(hello_str)
rate.sleep()
if __name__ == '__main__':
try:
talker()
except rospy.ROSInterruptException:
pass

Do not forget to make this file executable (chmod +x talker.py)
You only need to set it once
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

#!/usr/bin/env python

If you try to create a node using Python, the above line must
be at the top
It let the OS knows that this program should be passed to the
Python interpreter
import rospy

This line should be in all Pyhton node
It imports all of the basic functionality that we will need
from std_msgs.msg import String

We are going to publish messages of type String
We need to import String from the standard message
std msg.msg.

Publisher and Subscriber

 talker.py
pub = rospy.Publisher('chatter', String, queue_size=1)

This create an object of type Publisher and can be referred
to by the variable named pub
rospy.Publisher() is a constructor:
First Argument: The topic name (chatter)
Second Argument: The type of message (String)
Third Argument: The maximum number of message that will
be stored in case any subscriber is not receiving them fast
enough
rospy.init_node('talker', anonymous=True)

Initialize this node with the name talker
Should be anonymous
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 talker.py
rate = rospy.Rate(10) # 10hz

Create an object of type Rate and can be referred to by the
variable named rate
rospy.Rate() is a constructor
The argument 10 specifies the frequency in Hertz

rate.sleep() will be used later which will put this node to
sleep for 1/frequency second (0.1 second in this case).
while not rospy.is_shutdown():

A loop is a fairly standard rospy construct.
This node should stop if it gets a signal to shutdown.
rospy.is shutdown() return True if this node gets the
signal to shutdown.
The other way to simply shut this node down is by pressing
Ctrl-c on the console that this node is executing.

Publisher and Subscriber

 Subscriber

A subscriber subscribes to receive data from topics
A subscriber has to have a name (for debugging purpose)
A topic is a named bus (need a name as well)
A topic must have a type associated with it (strongly typed)
Do not need to care who are publishers (anonymous)

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 listener.py

#!/usr/bin/env python
import rospy
from std_msgs.msg import String
def callback(data):
rospy.loginfo(rospy.get_caller_id() + "I heard %s", data.data)
def listener():
rospy.init_node('listener', anonymous=True)
rospy.Subscriber("chatter", String, callback)
rospy.spin()
if __name__ == '__main__':
listener()

Do not forget to make this file executable (chmod +x talker.py)

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 listener.py
rospy.init_node('listener', anonymous=True)

Initialize this node with the name listener
Should be anonymous
rospy.Subscriber("chatter", String, callback)

Subscribes to the topic named chatter.
The type of message is String (must be the same as the
publisher)
Every time a message is received, call the function
callback()
rospy.spin()

Keeps the node from exiting until the node has been
shutdown.
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 The callback() Function

This callback() function will be called every time it receives
a message on the topic chatter:
def callback(data):
rospy.loginfo(rospy.get_caller_id() + "I heard %s", data.data)

The argument data has type std msgs/String
A data of this type consists of one component of type string
named data

To access the actual string, we use data.data like C structure

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 messenger.py

Sometimes your ROS node may behave like a middle man
Subscribes to a topic to receive data
Processes data
Publishes new data to a new topic

Example: Blob Detection
Subscribes to a topic to receive a series of image
For each image received, find blobs of a specific color, and
calculate the middle point of each blob
Publishes an array of coordinates of blobs

This type of node subscribes as well as publishes data
Example:
messenger node subscribe to the topic chatter1 and publish
the modified message to the topic chatter2

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 messenger.py
#!/usr/bin/env python
import rospy
from std_msgs.msg import String
pub = rospy.Publisher('chatter2', String, queue_size=10)
def chatterCallback(data):
global pub
messenger_str = "Messenger heard %s" % data.data
pub.publish(messenger_str);
def messenger():
rospy.init_node('messenger', anonymous=True)
rospy.Subscriber("chatter1", String, chatterCallback)
rospy.spin()
if __name__ == '__main__':
messenger()

Publisher and Subscriber

 Notes about Distributed Computing
ROS environment is similar to distributed environment.
Requires a number of processes to work together to finish a
job.
If a process dies, the whole thing will not work properly.
We need to make sure that each process is alive until the job is
done.

Generally, if a program finish, its process dies (exit).
In ROS, there are two main methods to keep a process alive.
Loop until a job is done.
while not rospy.is_shutdown():
:

Use rospy.spin() which is almost the same as
while not rospy.is_shutdown():
pass

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 Loop vs rospy.spin()

You should use either loop or rospy.spin() but not both in
the same program.
Use loop when your program has to continuously checking
and doing something.
Continuously publishes messages.
Continuously monitors variable values.

Use rospy.spin() when you program can go to sleep until
something happen.
Process an image or data whenever it is available (subscriber),
publish just one message, and go back to sleep.

Often time, the choice of loop vs rospy.spin() is not clear.

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 Cleanup
A process (node) can be killed by pressing Ctrl-c or receiving
the kill signal from ROS master
Sometime, a process needs to clean up before exit.
If robot is currently moving, stop it first and exit
Otherwise, robot may keep moving non-stop

Cleanup can be done by registering shutdown hooks:
def cleanup():
# stop the robot
rospy.on_shutdown(cleanup)

When the program receive the kill signal, it will call the
function cleanup() first and then exit
A node can manually shut itself down.
rospy.signal_shutdown("I am done.")

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 About Callback Functions
Recall the listener node.
#!/usr/bin/env python
import rospy
from std_msgs.msg import String
def callback(data):
rospy.loginfo(rospy.get_caller_id() + "I heard %s", data.data)
def listener():
rospy.init_node('listener', anonymous=True)
rospy.Subscriber("chatter", String, callback)
rospy.spin()
if __name__ == '__main__':
listener()

The function callback() will be called every time a message
from the topic chatter is received.

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 About Callback Functions
Rule of Thumb:
A callback function should be as short as possible
If you need to process a large data (e.g., image), the
processing part should not be in the callback function
The callback should simply update global variables and let the
program process it when it is ready to process.
:
from copy import deepcopy
image = None
def aCallback(data):
image = data
def mainProgram():
:
while not rospy.is_shutdown():
:
copyImage = deepcopy(image)
# process copyImage
:

 rostopic
rostopic is a tool related to topics in ROS environment
It allows us to perform the following:
List the current active topics
Show messages publish to a specific topic on screen
Publish a message to a specific topic
Show information about a specific topic
Show type of a specific topic

Suppose we run the talker and listener node using the
following commands in three separate console screen:
roscore
rosrun mypackage talker.py
rosrun mypackage listener.py

Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 rostopic
Use
rostopic list

to list the active topics on the console screen.
/chatter
/rosout
/rosout_agg

Use
rostopic echo chatter

to show messages published to the topic chatter
data: hello from talker 1463668746.93
--data: hello from talker 1463668747.03
--data: hello from talker 1463668747.23
--data: hello from talker 1463668747.33
--:

Publisher and Subscriber

 rostopic
Use
rostopic info chatter

to show information about the topic chatter
Type: std_msgs/String
Publishers:
* /talker_4544_1463668570440 (http://r2-d2:56659/)
Subscribers:
* /listener_4723_1463668575785 (http://r2-d2:35408)

Use
rostopic type chatter

to show the type of the topic chatter
std_msgs/String

To publish the string "Blah Blah Blah" to the topic
chatter
rostopic pub /chatter std_msgs/String "Blah Blah Blah"
Thumrongsak Kosiyatrakul

Publisher and Subscriber

 Workspace Directory

Your workspace directory is
/home/[username]/cs1567/src/mypackage

All Python program should be in
/home/[username]/cs1567/src/mypackage/scripts

or any subdirectory under the above directory.
To quickly change to ../mypackage directory, you can simply
type
roscd my[Tab]

where [Tab] is the Tab button on your keyboard.
